article:
and terrestrial vegetation. Dark blue and green indicate regions of high
 photosynthetic activity in ocean and land respectively.]] 'Photosynthesis' is a
 process used by plants and other organisms to convert the light energy captured
 from the sun into chemical energy that can be used to fuel the organism's
 activities. Carbon dioxide and water are used by plants to synthesize
 carbohydrates such as sugars, hence the name photosynthesis, from the Greek [photo-
 ], "light," and [synthesis], "putting together". Oxygen is also released,
 mostly as a waste product. Most plants, most algae, and cyanobacteria perform
 the process of photosynthesis. These photosynthetic organisms are called
 [[photoautotroph]]s because they can feed themselves on their own
 photosynthetic products. On the other hand, archaea, animals, and fungi do not
 photosynthesize. Photosynthesis is responsible for maintaining normal levels of
 atmospheric oxygen, is the source of carbon within organic compounds in the
 bodies of all organisms and also the source of energy for nearly all life on
 Earth, the exception being chemoautotrophs which
 live near deep sea vents.

Although photosynthesis is performed differently by different species, the
process always begins when energy from light is absorbed by proteins called
reaction centres that contain green chlorophyll pigments. In plants, these
proteins are held inside organelles called chloroplasts, which are most abundant
in leaf cells, while in bacteria they are embedded in the plasma membrane. The
absorbed light energy triggers sets of cyclic and non-cyclic light-dependant
reactions. In the non-cyclic (Z-scheme) reactions, some energy is used to strip
electrons from suitable substances such as water, producing oxygen and hydrogen
ions through photolysis. These electrons and hydrogen ions are transferred to a
compound called nicotinamide adenine dinucleotide phosphate (NADP), reducing it
to NADPH. In both cyclic and non-cyclic reactions, more light energy is
transferred to chemical energy in the generation of adenosine triphosphate
(ATP), the "energy currency" of cells.

The light-independent reactions produce carbohydrates from carbon dioxide. These
reactions require the electrons of NADPH and the chemical energy of ATP, both of
which were produced by the light-dependant reactions. In plants, algae and
cyanobacteria, the production of sugars is done by a sequence of reactions
called the Calvin cycle, but some bacteria use different sets of reactions, such
as the reverse Krebs cycle. In the Calvin cycle, atmospheric carbon dioxide is
incorporated into already existing organic carbon compounds, such as ribulose
bisphosphate (RuBP), through a process called carbon fixation. The resulting compounds are then reduced by NADPH into triose
phosphate. Of every six triose phosphate molecules produced, one is removed to
form further carbohydrates, and five are used to regenerate the carbon dioxide
acceptor, RuBP, thus completing the reaction cycle.

The first photosynthetic organisms probably evolved about , early in the
evolutionary history of life, when all forms of life on Earth were
microorganisms and the atmosphere contained much higher concentrations of carbon
dioxide than in the last half billion years or so. The earliest photosynthetic
organs probably used reducing agents such as hydrogen or hydrogen sulfide as
sources of electrons, rather than water.
Cyanobacteria appeared later, around ; the excess oxygen that they produced
drastically changed life on Earth when its concentration began to dominate the
chemistry of the atmosphere. This began to happen about .

This new oxygen-rich atmosphere rendered the evolution of complex life possible,
beginning with organisms like protists. Eventually, no later than a billion
years ago, some of these protists formed a symbiotic relationship with
cyanobacteria, producing the ancestor of photosynthetic plants and algae. The chloroplasts in modern plants are the descendants
of these ancient symbiotic cyanobacteria. Today,
the average rate of energy capture by photosynthesis globally is approximately
130 terawatts, which is
about six times larger than the current power consumption of human
civilization. Photosynthetic organisms also convert around
100â115 thousand million metric tons (i.e., 100â115 petagrams) of carbon
into biomass per year.
